sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Among the medicinal mushrooms β-glucans are the most extensively explored group of bioactive substance. The structure of β-glucans consists of β-(1–3) backbone branched with short β-(1–6) linked side chains (Grundemann et al. 2015; Su et al. 2016). Glycosidic bond connects repeating units of either mono-or disaccharides to form polysaccharides, named as glucans. They are heterogenic in nature and represent nonallergic, water insoluble cell wall constituents. In some plants, fungi and bacteria are different in bonding pattern (either in alpha (α) or beta (β)) and in repeating units with branching positions of (1–2, 1–3, 1–4 and 1–6) (Ruthes et al. 2015). The AgNPs are synthesized by different polysaccharides like β-d-glucose, soluble starch, starch, cashew gum, hyaluronic acid and chitosan. β-Glucans can also be utilized for preparation of AgNPs or other nano-sized metal structures, because they can reduce metal ions like Au, Ag, Pt and prevent the * Asma Irshad asmairshad76@yahoo.com; asma.irshad@cemb.edu.pk 1 National Centre of Excellence in Molecular Biology, University of the Punjab, Lahore 54000, Pakistan 2 Department of Computer Science, Bahria University Lahore Campus, Lahore, Pakistan 3 Department of Biotechnology, BUITEM, Quetta, Pakistan 4 Department of Allied Health Sciences, Sargodha Medical College, University of Sargodha, Sargodha, Pakistan 5 College of Biosystem Engineering and Food Science, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China 6 Department of Biochemistry, University of Agriculture, Faisalabad, Pakistan 7 Institute of Pharmacy, Physiology and Pharmacology,
University of Agriculture, Faisalabad, Pakistan
1 3
aggregation of the nano-particles (Glisic et al. 2015). The ‘biological response modifiers’ (BRMs) is a term often used to describe β-glucans for their ability to elicit immune system’s non-specific reactions against cancerous cells, bacterial and viral infections (Grundemann et al. 2015). These heteropolysaccharides or macromolecules attain specific activities from their monomers depending on the structure and bonding pattern, have acquired importance as nutraceuticals in health sector, and play vital role in medicines, specifically in handling of immunodeficiency, cancer or random immunosuppression associated with medicine treatment, in joint treatment with antibiotics and as additional component for vaccines (Buddana et al. 2015). P. sajor-caju contains a potential immunological enhancer, non-cellulosic β-glucans used medically in Japan and China (Moharib et al. 2014). Instead of gold-based compounds, silver-based ones are economical to a greater extent which is why they are largely being used as catalyst or antifungal/antibacterial substances now days (Rauwel et al. 2015). Hence, we can say that AgNPs have been employed in biology and medicine many times owing to their catalytic and antibacterial properties (Krishnaraj et al. 2016). Nano-particles (NPs) are typically lesser than 100 nm in size. Their smaller mass and high surface-to-volume ratio accounts for their bactericidal efficiency, which facilitates close interactions with bacterial membranes. Various mechanisms have been put forward for silver nano-particles to do cell lysis or inhibition of growth and development. The paralysis of enzyme action by SH-group reaction provides a proof of lethality of silver for bacteria (Salem et al. 2015). Particles of nano-silver were effectively manufactured with leaf extracts of Calliandra haematocephala. The silver nano-particles got illustrated by UV–Vis spectrophotometry. The structure of silver nano-particles was portrayed by scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectroscopy was performed to determine the presence of elemental Ag. For the identification of the crystalline nature and purity level of the silver nano-particles, X-ray diffraction technique was used which confirmed the existence of (111) and (220) lattice planes of the face centered cubic (fcc) structure of Ag metal. FTIR was brought into play to find out the specific functional groups that cause the reduction and stabilization of silver nitrate to make silver nano-particles. Zeta potential calculations were performed to analyze the stability of the AgNPs. The antimicrobial potential against Escherichia coli (pathogenic bacteria) was confirmed which in future will find function in the development of new antibacterial drugs (Raja et al. 2015).

sections.heading: Extraction of glucans
sections.text: The dry selected mushrooms powder (100 g) was treated with hot water at 60 °C for 3 h. Both were taken in ratio of (1:30 w/w), then filtered, concentrated under reduced pressure at 60 °C (rotary evaporator). After that mixed 95% ethanol and extracts (1:3 ratio, v/v) and kept overnight (4 °C) for precipitation of sample and centrifuged at 5000×g for 20 min. Then freeze-dried the precipitates and labeled as crude polysaccharides (Novak et al. 2011). Fractionation and purification was performed by following the method while confirmation was performed through phenol sulfuric acid essay by following the method of Zhang et al. (2012). Preparation of silver nano-particles using glucans from Pleurotus spps. by following the method of Synytsya et al. (2009).

sections.heading: Characterization of mushroom glucans and glucan‑coated silver nano‑particles
sections.text:
The entire samples including mushroom glucans and glucan-coated silver nano-particles were characterized by the following techniques.
Ultraviolet visible spectroscopy Ultraviolet–visible spectrometer was used to perform (UV/Vis) spectroscopic analysis. The sample solution of mushroom glucans and glucan-coated silver nano-particles were prepared by use of distilled water. The UV–Vis measurements were calculated in 190–500 nm. The spectrum of the samples was recorded in the above-mentioned range (Zhang et al. 2012).
Dynamic light scattering (DLS) A Malvern (ZetaSizer) Nano (ZS) apparatus (UK) working at a light source wavelength (532 nm) and a fixed scattering angle (173°) was employed to determine particles size of mushroom glucancoated silver nano-particles SNP1, SNP3, SNP6 and SNP8, respectively. Dynamic light scattering analyses were done on 1.0 mm of the sample positioned in a cell. Calculations were performed in a (1.0 cm) optical path cell with particular regulation of temperature at 25 °C (Bastus et al. 2014).
Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) FT-IR analysis was performed on mushroom glucans and glucan-coated silver nano-particles samples to determine their functional groups. Studies of infrared spectra were performed on Fourier transform infrared spectrometer in the dry air (room temperature). Potassium bromide pellet was employed for the determination of Fourier transform infrared spectra from the samples on a (FT-IR) spectrophotometer (Zhang et al. 2012).
Scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersion spectroscopy All mushroom glucans and glucan-coated silver
1 3
nano-particles samples were characterized for surface morphology using scanning electron microscope (FEI Quanta 250, Czech Republic). The elemental analysis will be performed by EDS (Oxford, INCA, USA). The observation of the SEM–EDS of the glucan and glucan–AgNPs were performed by using the protocol given by Fujita et al. (2003).
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) All the mushroom glucan-coated silver nano-particles samples were characterized for internal structure analysis by using transmission electron microscope (JOEL, JEM1010, Japan). The observation of the TEM of the glucan-coated silver nanoparticles was performed by using the protocol given by Morsy et al. (2014).
X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The phase purity of prepared products (mushroom glucans and glucan-coated silver nano-particles) was determined by X-ray diffraction using (PANalytical ´X´ pert PRO, The Netherlands) (Jung et al. 2013).

sections.heading: Result and discussions
sections.text: Nature continuously synthesizes enormous amount of polysaccharides which help for the most part as storage carbohydrates like starch and glycogen or organizational scaffolds like chitin in animals and cellulose in plants. A special group of β-1,3 linked polyglucose usually named β-glucan or glucan is extensively present in various bacteria, fungi, mushrooms, algae and higher plants. Polysaccharide from mushrooms have attracted attention because of bioactive and medicinal properties such as immunomodulatory, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, anti-infective, cholesterol lowering, antiviral, radioprotective, antitumoral and woundhealing (Kogan, 2000).

sections.heading: Extraction and purification of glucans
sections.text:
Crude polysaccharides were originated from particular mushrooms by hot water extraction. The extracts were fractionated and purified by anion exchange chromatography. Crude polysaccharides 500 mg were mixed in 10 mL and loaded (DEAE-cellulose 52 column). The elution of polysaccharide was examined by phenol sulfuric acid analysis. The key fractions were further refined with gel filtration chromatography (Sephadex G-200 column). Refined polysaccharide fraction were achieved and lyophilized for further investigations (Fig. 1).
Synthesis of glucan‑coated silver nano‑particles (glucan–AgNPs)
The silver nano-particles (Ag0) are formed by reduction of silver ions (Ag+), which results in alteration of light
yellow color to dark brown color that is indication of synthesis associated with silver nano-particles. Silver nanoparticles display powerful absorbance at 380–420 nm within the visible region because of surface plasmon resonance (Drzewiecka et al. 2014; Morsy et al. 2014) (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: UV–Vis spectroscopic analysis of glucans and glucan‑coated silver nano‑particles
sections.text:
Mushroom glucans and AgNO3 were employed for the formation of AgNPs. This process included the eco-friendly preparation of silver nano-particles through autoclaving. The polysaccharides behave as stabilizing and reducing compound in preparation of silver nano-particles. Following autoclave the silver nano-particles are sterile and clean (Kora et al. 2010). The polysaccharides spread so that they are much more available for silver ions to react with functional group. In this process carbonyl group is formed by oxidation of hydroxyl group to brought on the existence of Ag+, these Ag+ obtained are reduced to much needed silver element. The detection of glucans as well as glucan-coated AgNPs can be done by absorption spectrum through UV–Vis spectroscopy. Actually synthesized glucan–AgNPs were studied by spectral evaluation around UV/Visible region of 380–420 nm. This was the very readily employed, easy as well as delicate method of the verification of AgNPs. The actual spectra from each tend to be proven in Fig. 3.
In the graphs, the peaks existing at lower absorbance region were due to the glucans and the peaks present at higher absorbance region were due to glucan-coated AgNPs (Fig. 3). Glucans show powerful peak close to 190–250 nm (a1). AgNPs synthesized through glucan show powerful peak close to 380–420 nm (a2). Peaks only at that array tend to be because of surface plasma resonance (SPR); this accounts for transfer of electron on the surface of AgNPs. The actual darkish yellow color associated with glucan–AgNPs is attained by the surface plasma resonance changeover (Bankura et al. 2012). There have been
1 3
absolutely no peaks around 314–500 nm may be the verification associated with absolutely no nanocluster development or even aggregation of nano-contaminants (Kora et al. 2010).
Dynamic light scattering (DLS) of glucan‑coated silver nano‑particles
Regardless of basic and technical significance, the process associated with artificial controlling of the size as well as surface chemistry of AgNPs has attained restricted achievement (Sondi et al. 2003). The synthetic path offers
1 3
consequences in the particular control of size of AgNPs in range of 10–200 nm, providing the benefit of having the ability to make durable and stable AgNPs with size distributions in narrow range, higher concentration as well as easily obtainable surface through thiol (–SH), amine-terminated substances and protein (Casals et al. 2011). Bastus et al. (2014) has synthesized sodium citrate-coated silver nanoparticles with controlled sizes ranging from 10 to 200 nm through the reduction of silver nitrate via two chemical reducing agents: sodium citrate and tannic acid. This procedure produces durable sodium citrate-coated silver nano-particles with controlled size and readily accessible surfaces. In present research, we have reported the size of glucan–AgNPs for Pleurotus ostreatus, at 100.1 nm through dynamic light scattering (Fig. 4).

sections.heading: Characterization of glucans and glucan‑coated silver nano‑particles
sections.text:
Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (FT‑IR)
Infrared spectroscopy provides us details about confirmation of the existence of various functional groups for example C=O, N–H and O–H as well as concerning molecular framework. Numerous functional groups can be found within the natural substances. The vibration of groups in the segments of polymer impact on the intermolecular associations; these details can be acquired through performing FT-IR estimation. FT-IR spectra from the glucans as well as glucancoated AgNPs were documented and characteristic wave numbers were detected.
Spectra associated with glucans and glucan–AgNPs of P. ostreatus are shown in Fig. 5a, b. Within the spectra of glucans Fig. 5a, the broad peak 3298.25 cm−1 was examined, which was because of the stretched behavior associated with O–H bond. The broad peak at 2916.96 cm−1 was because of stretched behavior associated with C–H group. Two absorption peaks at 1011.66 cm−1 and within the region of
1000–1200 cm−1 (mainly CC and CO extending vibrations within pyranoid rings) demonstrated that pyranose was the actual monosaccharide within the raw polysaccharides and in addition, it demonstrated that polysaccharides were the main elements. An extensive peak made appearance at about 1647.53 cm−1 as well as tiny peak at about 1357.88 cm−1 verified the existence associated with carboxyl group. Within the spectra of glucan–AgNPs Fig. 5b, peak at about 3409.50 cm−1 represented the presence of glucan-coated silver nano-particles. The peak of O–H bond at 3298.25 cm−1 became narrow and shifted to 3409.50 cm−1 due to conjugation of glucans with silver nano-particles.
The actual spectra associated with glucan by four different Pleurotus spps. are shown in Fig. 5. They expressed a number of concentrated, extremely overlapped IR bands in the range of 950–1200 cm−1 (mainly CC as well as CO stretched vibrations within pyranoid rings) showing the existence associated with glucans as the main element. Partly, the sharp peak at 1150–1160 cm−1 was designated to COC stretch associated with glycosidic bonds. The weak peak close to 894 cm−1 was particular with regard to β-glycosidic bond and consequently, signifies the existence of β-glucans. Additional peaks and shoulder designated to β-glucans were discovered close to 1376, 1317, 1162, 1100, 1080, 1040 as well as 990 cm−1.
Zhang et al. (2012) has reported that within the infrared spectrum from the purified glucans, the extensively stretched sharp band at about 3400 cm−1 signify the actual distinctive hydroxyl group along with a weaker peak pointed out at C-H group close to 2920 cm−1. The comparatively powerful absorption band close to 1640 cm−1 pointed out the feature associated with C=O. The absorbance of polysaccharides within the region of 950–1200 cm−1 tends to be due to the stretching vibration associated with C–O–C and C–O–H groups. The peaks in the region of 350–600 cm−1 designated to skeletal modes associated with pyranose bands. The peaks in the range of 1720 as well as 1251 cm−1 pointed out the traces of uronic acids as well as ester sulfate.
Scanning electron microscopy‑energy dispersion spectroscopy (SEM–EDS)
For detailed examination of the surface morphology, to figure out the actual morphological modifications within the structure and to confirm the organization associated with glucans as well as glucan–AgNPs, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out. Scanning electron microscopy verified that there were unique specifications within the surface morphology of glucans and glucan-coated AgNPs. There was a definite morphology of the glucans as well as glucan-coated AgNPs associated with various Pleurotus spps. The surfaces of these samples were scanned via magnification power of 1000 µm.
1 3
In general, the morphology of the representative images of mushroom glucans and glucan–AgNPs is shown in Fig. 6. Mushroom glucans show a porous and spongy appearance whereas; there were no visible traces of cell wall structure (Fig. 6a). There was obvious variation in the shape of the particles and size distribution. Extracted glucans show asymmetrical particle size distribution. The rounder, homogeneous and larger cluster was also observed. Bayer et al. (2014) performed scanning electron microscopy to report the spherical architecture of polysaccharides. Scanning electron microscopy was performed to investigate the assembled 3D porous structures of mushroom glucan-coated silver nano-particles (glucan–AgNPs) shown in Fig. 6b. The
SEM equipped with energy dispersive pattern (EDS) Model (Oxford, INCA, USA) provided the peaks for the confirmation of elemental analysis of AgNPs in glucan–AgNPs (Fig. 7). The same morphological features were investigated by (Jung et al. 2013; Rupiasih et al. 2013; Raja et al. 2015).

sections.heading: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
sections.text:
To examine the inside arrangement, to figure out the actual morphological modifications within the interior arrangement and also to confirm the organization associated with glucancoated AgNPs, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out Fig. 8. Transmission electron microscopy
1 3
verified that there was a specific interior arrangement of glucan-coated AgNPs of various Pleurotus spps. The structure of glucan–AgNPs was almost spherical for all Pleurotus spps. The actual interior arrangements of these samples were scanned via magnification power of 100 K at 80 kV.
The results of transmission electron microscope show nearly spherical architecture of glucan–AgNPs with a particle size range of 15–45 nm for glucan–AgNPs of all four Pleurotus ostreatus. The AgNPs were placed on a carboncoated copper grid prior to examine by TEM through a
1 3
high voltage of 80 kV (Jung et al. 2013). According to the transmission electron microscope images, the morphology of the Nostoc commune extracellular polysaccharide-coated AgNPs was observed. It was roughly circular with approximate size range of 15–45 nm (Morsy et al. 2014). Shankar et al. (2016) characterized pectin-coated silver nano-particles composite films by TEM and reported the resultant spherical shaped AgNPs with a size range of 20–80 nm. Chen et al. (2016) prepared silver nano-particles with a fungal exopolysaccharide in water, characterized by TEM and reported roughly round AgNPs of 50 nm diameter with narrow size range and stable dispersion. Our results of TEM were consistent with the study reported by Chen et al. (2016) with slight variations in the size of nano-particles. These variations in size were may be due to binding properties of the substrates or method used.

sections.heading: X‑ray diffraction (XRD) analysis
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction configurations of the original glucans and glucan-coated silver nano-particles of four Pleurotus spps. are shown in Fig. 8. The XRD spectra of glucan and glucan-coated silver nano-particles are represented as P.
ostreatus in Fig. 9a, b. The XRD spectra of glucan showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 5.9°, 10.1° and 19.6° which coincide with the reported data of polysaccharide biopolymers (Cho et al. 2014) as shown in Fig. 9a. The XRD spectra of glucan-coated silver nano-particles exhibited band diffraction peak for silver nano-particles at 2θ = 38.2°, 44.5°, 64.7° and 77.5° corresponding Braggs reflection planes acquired as: for peak 1 have plane (111), for peak 2 have plane (200), peak 3 have plane (220) and peak 4 have plane (311) confirmed by the help of TEM. The structure was face centered cubic (fcc) of silver crystal (Fig. 9b; Tables 1, 2).
The XRD spectra of glucans showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 5.9°, 10.1° and 19.6°, which coincide with the reported data of polysaccharide polymers. Under highpressure homogenization, the intensity characteristics of the peaks tend to decrease as the number of passes increase.
Table 1 XRD pattern peak for glucans from Pleurotus spps. Peak no. Angle 2θ
1 5.9 2 10.1 3 19.6

The destruction of the crystal structure of the β-glucan resulted in the decline in crystallinity due to cleavage of the glycosyl bonds. During high-pressure homogenization this could be attributed to the cavitation, high-energy shear and impact effects. This result appears to be in good agreement with the data on the molecular weight and viscosity of the β-glucan (Cho et al. 2014). AgNPs have been verified through XRD analysis. The actual XRD design exhibits four apparent bands at 38°, 44°, 64° and 77° that are designated to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of the face centered cubic (fcc) of silver crystal. The actual band close to 21.9 was because of condensed crystalline chitosan (Jung et al. 2013). The silver nano-particles against Braggs reflection planes of (222), (400) and (420) in X-ray diffraction, showed diffraction at 2θ = 34.48°, 40.12° and 45.39° in pattern (Rupiasih et al. 2013). Raja et al. (2015) determined the crystalline nature and purity level of the silver nano-particles through XRD technique, which established the existence of (111) and (220) lattice planes of the face centered cubic (fcc) morphology of silver metal. Our results were comparable with Rupiasih et al. (2013), Cho et al. (2014) and Raja et al. (2015). The variations in results were may be due to binding properties of the substrates.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, UV/Vis, FT-IR, SEM–EDS, TEM and XRD have confirmed characteristic features of glucan and glucan–AgNPs. We have also found that the potentials of AgNPs were enhanced by its conjugation with glucans in glucan–AgNPs. Furthermore, glucans and glucan–AgNPs were made without any impurities. The results were within approximate ranges of each other and the values reported in previous studies. These values may differ due to different species of mushrooms.

metadata.abstractText: The extensive use of antibiotics has led to drug-resistant bacteria, which is a major public health issue worldwide. Silver nano-particles have been recognized as efficient broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent. It uses mushroom glucans as reducing and capping agent to reduce its toxicity. In the present work, we performed the characterization of glucans and glucan– AgNPs. The crude glucans were extracted by hot water then fractionated and purified by anion exchange chromatography (DEAE-cellulose 52); the elution of glucans was monitored by phenol sulfuric acid assay. The major fractions were further purified with gel filtration chromatography (Sephadex-G200) then lyophilized. Green synthesis of silver nano-particles was performed by glucans from selected Pleurotus spps. Extracted glucans and synthesized glucan–AgNPs were confirmed by UV–Vis spectra at 190–250 nm and 380–420 nm, respectively. Size of glucan–AgNPs (100.1 nm) was determined by dynamic light scattering. The glucans were characterized by FT-IR, SEM and XRD while glucan–AgNPs were characterized by FT-IR, SEM–EDS, TEM and XRD. Based on FT-IR spectra, the functional groups associated with the glucans and glucan–AgNPs were determined. SEM analysis revealed that the structure of glucan was spongy with asymmetrical particle size while SEM–EDS/TEM analysis revealed the glucan–AgNPs were spherical with size range of 15–45 nm for Pleurotus ostreatus. XRD spectra of glucan showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 5.9°, 10.1° and 19.6°. By SEM–EDS/TEM analysis, the silver nano-particles against Braggs reflection planes of (111), (200), (220) and (311) in X-ray diffraction, showed diffraction at 2θ = 38.2°, 44.5°, 64.7° and 77.5° in pattern.
